org.schwering.evi.core
Class ModuleFactory

java.lang.Object
  org.schwering.evi.core.ModuleFactory
public final class ModuleFactory
extends java.lang.Object

Provides methods to instantiate and dispose a module.
When a module is instantiated, this new instance is registered in the module's ModuleContainer. And the newInstance / disposeInstance methods cause IModuleListener events to be fired. Hence, it is necessary to use this class's methods to instantiate and dispose a module to keep the internal mechanisms faultless!

Zhis class adds a shutdownhook that invokes disposeInstance for each module instance when the client is shut down. (This shutdownhook is added in a static block; this means it is added automatically when this class is loaded.)

Version:
$Id$
Author:
Christoph Schwering (mailto:schwering@gmail.com)
See Also:
ModuleLoader, ModuleContainer, IModuleListener

Method Detail

newInstance

public static IModule newInstance(ModuleContainer module)
                           throws ModuleInstantiationException
Creates a new instance of the given module. The method also registers the instance internally and fires the IModuleListener.instantiated(IModule) event.

Parameters:
module - The module.
Returns:
The module's instance.
Throws:
ModuleInstantiationException - If something fails (e.g. no constructor).
See Also:
newInstance(ModuleContainer, Object[]), disposeInstance(IModule)

newInstance

public static IModule newInstance(ModuleContainer module,
                                  java.lang.Object[] args)
                           throws ModuleInstantiationException
Creates a new instance of the given module, optionally with arguments. The method also registers the instance internally and fires the IModuleListener.instantiated(IModule) event.

If the module was loaded from a JAR with a IModuleInfo information class:

  • If args is null, the module is tried to be instantiated without arguments using IModuleInfo.newInstance().
  • If args has just one element and if this element is an instance of java.net.URI and if the module is a URI handler, the instance is created using the method IURIHandler.newInstance(URI).
  • Otherwise, if the module is parameterizable, the args are passed to the module using the IParameterizable.newInstance(Object[]) method.
  • Otherwise, an exception is thrown.

If the module was loaded as single class using ModuleLoader.load(Class)

  • If args is null, a constructor is searched that takes no arguments. If it is found, the constructor is used to create a new instance.
  • Otherwise, a constructor is searched that matches the types of the objects in args. The constructor is invoked and the new instance is returned.
  • Otherwise, an exception is thrown.

Parameters:
module - The module.
args - The constructors arguments.
Returns:
The module's instance.
Throws:
ModuleInstantiationException - If something fails (e.g. no constructor).
See Also:
newInstance(ModuleContainer), disposeInstance(IModule)

disposeInstance

public static boolean disposeInstance(IModule instance)
Fires the IModuleListener.disposed(IModule) event, unregisters the module internally and invokes IModule.dispose().
Why should you call ModuleFactorydisposeInstance(module) instead of calling module.dispose() directly?
Because (as told two lines above) this method does more than just calling dispose(): it also unregisters the instance internally and fires the respective event.

Parameters:
instance - The module.
Returns:
true if the module is unregistered successfully.
